awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase I:  Innovative dispersion technology for the sustainable repurposing of off-spec and recycled carbon fiber into low-cost, defect-free, nonwoven fabrics
awd_abstract_narration:
The Broader impact of this Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project is to intercepting landfill-destined carbon fiber – designated as off-spec fibers - and repurpose it into sustainable nonwoven fabrics. Off-spec carbon fiber constitutes 30% of carbon fiber production. These sustainable fabrics will be categorized based on their performance characteristics into multiple tiers that are suitable for different scales of applications. In addition, this project will explore the hybridization of natural fiber and off-spec carbon fiber for increased sustainability. The results of this project may serve as a baseline for industry to adopt these fabrics into their composites to create lighter automotive vehicles with lower emissions. The advanced composites made from the resulting fabrics may introduce new, high-performance materials that can be used for the development of medical devices, lightweight unmanned aircrafts, and electronic enclosures with applications in the automotive, aerospace, sporting, and marine industries, and beyond.

The proposed innovation to produce nonwoven fabrics from off-spec carbon fiber is based on the fundamental studies of their physical and chemical properties and their responses to mechanical agitation and suspension in an aqueous solutions. This effort focuses on dispersing mechanisms for the wet laid process. This technology may lead to a mathematical model that can receive inputs about fibers properties and predict a mixing regime that will provide dispersion conditions for an optimal nonwoven fabric. Such models can be supported with thorough, standardized, quality control and mechanical testing. This project objectives are to establish process to fabricate mats using off-spec materials, including trims, and recycled fibers and to optimize operations for mats made from different combinations of blended carbon fiber tiers. Mixtures of different fractional percentages and types of on- and off-spec carbon fibers will be used, and models will be adjusted to reflect optimal operational settings.  Finally, the team will compare the performance of tailored mixed-material carbon fiber mats against those produced using only carbon fibers to expand products applications.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Endeavor Composites has developed an innovative mixer for the dispersion of carbon fiber (CF) in the nonwoven method known as wet laid. The resulting mats are capable of producing advanced composites using sustainable, low-cost processes, with applications in the automotive, aerospace, sporting, industrial, marine industries, and beyond. Although these industries have shown strong interest in advanced composites for their durability and high strength-to-weight ratio, current fabrication materials have hindered their widespread adoption: while nonwoven mats are significantly more cost-efficient, they have historically not been preferred due to the presence of defects related to difficulty in dispersing and orienting fibers well enough to yield standardized mats. The high cost of manufacturing reproducible CF nonwoven mats has thus hindered their adoption, representing an unmet market need for low-cost CF fabrics.

Endeavor’s technology addresses this need by leveraging an innovative yet cost-effective wet-laid hydroentanglement process that enables the fabrication of highly reproducible, non-woven CF mats composed of fibers with unmatched aspect ratios (up to 5200). Further, our technology progresses customers’ sustainability targets on multiple fronts: 1) from a production standpoint, we are able to use on- and off-spec fibers, including those recycled from trims/scraps and commingled fabrics that would otherwise go to waste (e.g., the 36,000 tons/year of off-spec fibers currently sent to landfills), and 2) the resulting materials can be used, in the automotive and aerospace industries for example, as lightweight components that improve mile/gallon efficiency and reduce energy/fossil fuel demands. Finally, 3) The innovative mixer requires 10 times less water than other wet laid manufacturing processes.

In this NSF Phase I project, Endeavor Composites succeeded in using the wet laid method to produce nonwoven fabrics incorporating off-spec carbon fibers (OCF), recycled carbon fibers (RCF), and virgin carbon fibers (VCF), with fiber lengths of 24.5 mm. Two distinct fabric types were engineered: 1) A fabric comprised entirely of reinforcing fibers bonded with a Thermoset matrix to create composite materials, and 2) A blend containing 40% reinforcing fibers and 60% polypropylene (PP) fibers, which were subsequently compression molded into composite panels. Optimization work explored composition variations and reinforcement strategies, systematically adjusting the hemp to CF ratio as well as varying the grade of CF used (OCF, RCF, VCF). Notably, mechanical and functional testing results demonstrated a closer fidelity between the OCF to VCF than the RCF to OCF, pointing to the potential OCF fibers as a cost saving alternative to VCF. The findings from Phase I have effectively laid the groundwork for future work, where the potential of off-spec fibers as a viable structural reinforcement material will be further explored.

 


Last Modified: 05/09/2024
Modified by: Hicham Ghossein
